title: Windows PXE install; Multi-OS W2K to W8 (WAIK independent)

forumNotes.author: patpat
forumNotes.content:
Small windows app that automatically creates a menu of several Microsoft OSs for network (PXE) install.  
It network installs from Windows 2000 to Windows 8  
It runs from Windows 2000 to Windows 8  
(WAIK independent)  

read here:  
[http://www.vercot.co...indowsPXE1.html](http://www.vercot.com/~serva/howto/WindowsPXE1.html "External link")  

cheers...

forumNotes.author: patpat
forumNotes.content:
@Wonko  
You are probably right; I'll add those keywords you mention  

@steve6375  
I've purposely used 'restart' on the documentation trying to make people think of Serva as a service with a GUI but I'll consider your input on this.  

About your proxyDHCP question I think it is explained within the how-to, anyway basically the proxyDHCP announces itself when answering client's DHCP DISCOVERY packet. Then the client receives 2 OFFERS one from your DHCP and one from Serva as proxyDHCP from the first offer the client will continue DHCP regular process in order to take the assigned IP address and net mask, from the second offer after a unicast transaction to the proxyDHCP on port 4011 will get the TFTP/BINL server address and the name of the bootstrap loader. Let me know if you have any further doubt on this.  

About the winpe I generate, well it is just a "cold edited" version of the original Boot.wim what creates ServaBoot.wim.  
"cold edited" means that I edit the wim "w/o mounting the wim" nor requiring any WAIK dependant tool either; that's why you can run Serva even on W2000 and it'll be able to edit the wim w/o a hitch...  
The same for the creation of the bcd; it is also programmatically made w/o using WAIK tools nor registry mounting hive files or things like that.  

Something you guys probably did not notice yet is TFTP transfer speed for Vista SP1 and up..  
Serva implements a new TFTP negotiated parameter "windowsize" used by Microsoft what speed-up TFTP transfers dramatically  
Here the IETF [TFTP Windowsize option](http://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-masotta-tftpexts-windowsize-opt/ "External link") draft  
Here the [TFTP windowsize explanation](http://www.vercot.com/~serva/advanced/TFTP.html "External link")  

Best  
Pat

forumNotes.author: patpat
forumNotes.content:
> i.e. probably the two most useful (for MS OS tweaakers) pieces of software ever made and I use it internally to my app only. Please understand that Serva has been arround for 2 years now but Serva Binl (Serva 2.0.0) is 3 days old... I've been thinking of probably releasing tiny console apps for wim editing \& bcd creation but nothing concrete on this yet...
> Could you explain about this cold editing? Is it just patching bytes and if so how do you do it? I am sure many of us would be fascinated to know... Well the wim info is (with some errors) out there and there are a couple of projects that even when they do not quite well edit a wim they expose the wim structure pretty well... From a technical point of view it is kind of what you said, open the wim tables, load them in memory, parse the table structure then edit the table. > Is it possible to easily boot to grub4dos using this utility as a TFTP PXE server? you can boot to grub4dos; Serva is a PXE server... But you cannot boot to grub4dos as a BINL server, when you check the BINL option Serva takes controll of everything including the bootstrap loder used (PXELINUX derivative). I decided to go with SYSLINUX because I already made custom versions of it for Jeoss Linux and it never let me down.
